Authors:
Shun Liu, Yi-Fei Sun, Yan Wang, Tai-Min Xu, Chang-Ge Song,
Yuan-Yuan Chen, Bao-Kai Cui
Title:
Taxonomy and Molecular Phylogeny of Trametopsis (Polyporales,
Basidiomycota) with descriptions of two new species
Keywords:
Irpicaceae, multi-gene phylogeny, new species, white-rot
fungi, wood-decay fungi
Abstract:
Trametopsis is a genus distributed in Africa, Asia,
Europe, North America, South America and Oceania, with fewer species. It
grows on different angiosperm and gymnosperm trees and can cause white
decay of wood. Recent phylogenetic analyses showed that Trametopsis
belongs to Irpicaceae. in the phlebioid clade. In this study, we
performed taxonomic and phylogenetic appraisal of the genus Trametopsis.
Molecular phylogenetic analyses of multiple loci including the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS) regions, the large subunit nuclear ribosomal
RNA gene (nLSU), the translation elongation factor 1-α gene (TEF1), the
RNA polymerase II largest subunit (RPB1) and the second subunit of RNA
polymerase II (RPB2). Phylogenetic trees are inferred from the combined
datasets of 2-gene sequences and 5-gene sequences by using maximum
parsimony, maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference analyses. Combined
with molecular data, morphological characters and ecological traits, two
new species of Trametopsis are discovered. Trametopsis abieticola is
characterized by its pileate, solitary or imbricate basidiomata, pinkish
buff to buff-yellow pileal surface when fresh, becoming pinkish buff to
clay-buff when dry, cream to buff pore surface when fresh, becoming
pinkish buff to greyish brown upon drying, round to angular pores
(0.50.8 per mm), cylindrical basidiospores (5.87.2 × 1.92.6 μm),
distributed in the high altitude of mountains and grows on Abies sp.
Trametopsis tasmanica is characterized by its resupinate basidiomata,
cream to buff pore surface when fresh, becoming honey-yellow to snuff
brown upon drying, cylindrical basidiospores (5.26.3 × 1.82.2 μm),
distributed in Tasmania, Australia and grows on Eucalyptus sp. Detailed
descriptions and illustrations of the two novel species and
identification key to accepted species of Trametopsis are provided.
